Tidy data



Data tidying and importing

Author

Data Science with R

Tidy data

Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.

Leo Tolstoy

Characteristics of tidy data:

  • Each variable forms a column.
  • Each observation forms a row.
  • Each type of observational unit forms a table.

Characteristics of untidy data:

!@#$%^&*()

What makes this data not tidy?

Source: Army Air Forces Statistical Digest, WW II

What makes this data not tidy?

Source: Gapminder, Estimated HIV prevalence among 15-49 year olds

What makes this data not tidy?

Source: US Census Fact Finder, General Economic Characteristics, ACS 2017

What makes data tidy?

“Tidy datasets are easy to manipulate, model and visualise, and have a specific structure: each variable is a column, each observation is a row, and each type of observational unit is a table.”

. . .

Note

“easy to manipulate” = “straightforward to manipulate”

Wickham, H. (2014). Tidy data. Journal of statistical software, 59, 1-23.

Displaying vs. summarizing data

Display

# A tibble: 87 × 3
   name               height  mass
   <chr>               <int> <dbl>
 1 Luke Skywalker        172    77
 2 C-3PO                 167    75
 3 R2-D2                  96    32
 4 Darth Vader           202   136
 5 Leia Organa           150    49
 6 Owen Lars             178   120
 7 Beru Whitesun Lars    165    75
 8 R5-D4                  97    32
 9 Biggs Darklighter     183    84
10 Obi-Wan Kenobi        182    77
# ℹ 77 more rows

Summarize

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  gender    avg_ht
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 feminine    167.
2 masculine   177.
3 <NA>        175

Displaying vs. summarizing data

Display

starwars |>
  select(name, height, mass)

Summarize

starwars |>
  group_by(gender) |>
  summarize(
    avg_ht = mean(height, na.rm = TRUE)
  )
